importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 20, 2025, with AWS issuing an update around 9:34 AM UTC, marking the resolution of the outage and the timing of public awareness and response.

keyTakeAways: Amazon Web Services (AWS) resolved a global web outage caused by a DNS issue in its US-EAST-1 data center in Virginia.
The outage affected major platforms including Perplexity, Robinhood, Signal, Coinbase, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Duolingo, Canva, Wordle, Prime Video, and Alexa.
The root cause was identified as a problem with DynamoDB, a database service in the US-EAST-1 region.
Some users experienced throttled requests and were advised to flush their DNS caches.
The outage highlighted the critical role AWS plays as a foundational infrastructure provider for global digital services.
Financial institutions like the Bank of Scotland acknowledged the impact on UK customers, underscoring the broad reach of cloud outages.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) resolved a global web outage that originated from a DNS issue in DynamoDB, a database service within its US-EAST-1 data center in Virginia. The outage disrupted access to numerous major platforms, including Perplexity, Robinhood, Signal, Coinbase, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Duolingo, Canva, Wordle, Prime Video, and Alexa. Financial institutions like the Bank of Scotland also reported issues, underscoring the critical role AWS plays in supporting global digital infrastructure. While AWS confirmed the underlying issue was fully mitigated, users were advised to flush their DNS caches and some requests remained throttled during recovery. This incident highlights the vulnerability of internet-dependent services to failures in cloud computing platforms, even when they are built on highly scalable infrastructure.
title: Amazon Web Services says it has resolved issue behind global web outages
